metadata.title: Environmental indicator for effective control of COVID-19 spreading 2

abstract.text: Recently, a novel coronavirus has caused viral pneumonia worldwide, 21 spreading to more than 200 countries, posing a major threat to international health. To prevent 22 the spread of COVID-19, in this study, we report that the city lockdown measure was an 23 effective way to reduce the number of new cases, and the nitrogen dioxide (NO 2 ) concentration 24

can be adopted as an environmental lockdown indicator. In China, after strict city lockdown, the 25 average NO 2 concentration decreased 55.7% (95% confidence interval (CI): 51.5-59.6%) and 26 the total number of confirmed new cases decreased significantly. We also determined that the 27 global airborne NO 2 concentration steeply decreased over the vast majority of COVID-19-hit 28 areas based on satellite measurements. We found that if NO 2 emissions significantly decreased, 29 the total number of confirmed new cases reached an inflection point after approximately two 30 weeks. Italy, Germany and France are good examples. Our results suggest that NO 2 satellite 31 measurement can help decision makers effectively monitor control regulations to reduce the

body_text.text: Large-scale COVID-19 viral pneumonia through human-to-human transmission poses a 35 severe and acute public health emergency 1, 2 . As the epidemic worsened, most countries imposed 36 city lockdown and quarantine measures to reduce transmission to control the epidemic. The 37

Chinese government has gradually implemented a city-wide quarantine of Wuhan and several 38 surrounding cities as of 23 January, flights and trains to and from Wuhan have been suspended, 39 and public transport has been halted 3,4 . The entire northern Italy was quarantined since 9 March 40 2020, and three days later the government extended it to the whole country 5 .The Spanish 41 government declared a 15-day national emergency, starting on 15 March 6 . In the United States, 42 on 19 March, California became the first state to order a lockdown 7 . In Germany, since 18 March, 43 16 states have closed, public gatherings of more than two people have been banned and most 44 shops except supermarkets and pharmacies have closed 8 . On 23 March, the British government 45 announced a new nationwide restriction allowing residents to only venture outside when 46 absolutely necessary, e.g., to work, buy necessities 9 . 47

The worldwide lockdown, which was imposed to stop the spread of the novel coronavirus, 48 not only caused an economic downturn but also appeared to result in cleaner air in urban areas 49 usually heavily affected by pollution 10 . The most important measure of the lockdown policy was 50 the reduction of traffic and control personnel flow, and traffic pollution is an important factor 51 influencing air quality and public health. Vehicle exhaust and evaporation emissions are the main 52 emission sources of ozone and secondary particle precursors near the ground in cities and 53 regions 11 , and the spatial variation of nitrogen dioxide (NO 2 ), fine particulate matter (PM 2.5 ) and 54 black carbon (BC) may also be significant affected by traffic flow density 12

In South Korea, source analysis studies have shown that there is a 58 high correlation between estimated traffic volume and NO 2 concentration 14 . In Britain, road 59 transport accounts for 80% of the NO x emissions 15 . NO 2 levels can be used as a proxy for 60 exposure to traffic-related composite air pollution and to assess the impact of scenarios designed 61 to reduce traffic-related emissions 16,17 . 62 In this report, we study the parameters of environmental indicators for city lockdown. Using 63 the automatic ground detection data and satellite data to analyze the trend of lockdown and the 64 total confirmed new cases in major cities in China, and using satellite data to further study the 65 impact of lockdown on virus transmission in countries mainly severely affected by the epidemic, 66 in order to help policymakers to formulate effective control measures to reduce the spread of 67 COVID-19. 68 69

The monthly average PM 2.5 /PM 10 ratio was 0.81 (95% confidence 126 interval (CI): 0.76-0.86), so PM 2.5 was the main particle pollutant after lockdown. Exhaust 127 emissions contributed only moderately to local levels of the PM 2.5 total mass, which were mostly 128 derived from other sources, such as biomass combustion and the remote transmission of 129 secondary particles. Therefore, the impact of strict traffic control during the lockdown on PM 2.5 130 is not notable, and the spatial difference is large, so PM 2.5 is not suitable as a city lockdown 131 indicator. 132

body_text.text: Although the NO 2 emissions per vehicle slightly decreased after the upgrading of the 133 quality standards of petroleum products, the notable growth of vehicle ownership increased the 134 proportion of NO 2 traffic source emissions, in addition, after the implementation of emission 135 standards for coal-fired power plants, multiple technical improvements greatly controlled the 136 NO 2 emissions from coal-fired sources, which all enhanced the correlation between NO 2 and city 137 lockdown effect 21 . The effect of city closure on NO 2 was significantly greater than that on the 138 other pollutants, with an average concentration reduction of approximately 60.3% (95% CI: 139 56.8-64.0%), which can be applied as an environmental indicator of the lockdown effect. 140

body_text.text: Studies have shown that the likelihood of fewer cases in the gradual multi-stage policy is 234 zero, and that such a policy decision implies that the government is willing to risk an increase in 235 COVID19 cases and deaths in exchange for decreased economic and isolation impacts, which 236 may not be desirable from an objective point of view 29 . Although the immediate adoption of a 237 lockdown policy may lead to many people being adversely affected financially, in the short term, 238 the number of new confirmed cases will decline approximately 15 days after policy 239 implementation, and an earlier decline can occur with stricter lockdown measures. International 240 guidance supports a range of mandatory social isolation measures, extensive case detection, and 241 isolation and contact tracing 9 . Compliance with quarantine directives is absolutely critical to 242 saving lives, protecting the most vulnerable in society, and ensuring that the national security 243 system can cope and care for the sick. In such cases, an immediate lockdown policy may be 244 preferred, and NO 2 , as an environmental indicator of virus control, can help managers implement 245 effective control measured to curb the spread of COVID-19. 246

In 146 East Asia (Figure 2a), satellite images show that compared to before the blockade, the total 147 emissions of NO 2 in eastern China have significantly decreased by approximately 56.6%. In 148 South Korea, the monthly NO 2 emissions have also been reduced by approximately 18.0 %. The 149 local government has implemented the most expansive testing programme and has isolated 150 people infected with the virus without locking down entire cities, and the sharp decrease in NO 2 151 may be linked to the reduction in local emissions and pollutant transport from surrounding 152 areas 22,23 . Japan has not imposed widespread lockdown policies, and a 4.8% increase in NO 2 the north (82.4%), where the outbreak is the most severe. This could be due to the 156 reduction in road traffic and the decrease in economic activities in the industrial heartland as a 157 result of the widespread lockdown policy 10 . Other countries such as Germany, Denmark, and 158 Poland also experienced notable reductions. This is consistent with the results of the European 159 Environment Agency (EEA) 24 . However, in certain areas, such as northern and southern Spain, 160 the NO 2 concentration has risen, possibly because of lax closure measures and increased 161 emissions from coal-fired power plants 25 . FIGREF2.text: The temporal evolution of the NO 2 concentration with the total number of confirmed 172 new cases in China. After the strict city lockdown, the NO 2 concentration in the main 173 virus-affected cities in China decreased significantly (Figure 3). Consistent with the satellite data, 174 the ground monitoring results showed that compared to the conditions before the closure, the 175 monthly average NO 2 concentration after the lockdown decreased approximately 55.7% (95% CI: 176 51.5-59.6%). Since the lockdown, the total number of confirmed new cases reaches an inflection 177 point after approximately two weeks (the incubation period of the virus is 14 days), and 178 compared to the period of 1-15 days after the closure, the total number of confirmed new cases in 179 the 16-30 days after the closure has decreased 73.6% (95% CI: 64.9-81.1%). The most 180 significant improvement was recorded in Hangzhou, where the NO 2 concentration decreased 181 approximately 68.1%, and the total number of confirmed new cases declined the most. Likewise, 182 Zhengzhou, Changsha, Guangzhou, and Nanchang are good examples. Wuhan, the worst 183 virus-affected area in China, also exhibited a downward trend. The total number of confirmed 184 new cases reached 13,436 on February 12 due to the inclusion of clinically diagnosed cases 26 , 185 resulting in a new delayed peak in the figure. 186

The temporal evolution of the NO 2 concentration with the total number of confirmed 199 new cases in the COVID-19-hit areas globally. After the countries severely affected by 200 COVID-19 implemented strict lockdown measures, satellite data showed a significant decline in 201 NO 2 emissions, and the total confirmed new cases decreased after two weeks in most areas 202 (Figure 4). As a result, the strict lockdown of COVID-19-hit areas other than those in China is 203 also effective and easy to implement to prevent the spread of the virus. The lockdown measures 204 might have already prevented tens of thousands of deaths in Europe 28 . In Italy, where the 205 epidemic is widespread, after the lockdown the NO 2 emissions significantly decreased by an 206 average of 36.6%, and the total confirmed new cases reached an inflection point 12 days later, have been averted in this country due to the implemented intervention measures 28 . 209 The occurrence time of the inflection point is mainly related to the magnitude of NO 2 decline. In 210 France, NO 2 declined less (27.1%), and the time for the total number of confirmed new cases to 211 reach an inflection point was delayed. In Germany, the NO 2 emissions decreased the most, by 212 54.7%, and the total number of confirmed new cases reached an inflection point within 8 days 213 after lockdown, which occurred earlier than in other countries. For Iran and Switzerland, due to 214 the relatively low number of confirmed cases, with the decline of NO 2 after the strict control, 215 confirmed new cases also reached the inflection point earlier.
